verses.verse: Sennacherib Threatens Jerusalem (2 Kings 18.13; Isa 1.1) In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

(2 Kings 18.17-20; Isa 7.3) The king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh with a great army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. He stood by the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the fuller’s field.
(Isa 22.15, 20) And there came out to him Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder.
(2 Kings 18.19) The Rabshakeh said to them, “Say to Hezekiah: Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you base this reliance of yours?
(2 Kings 18.7) Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? On whom, then, do you now rely, that you have rebelled against me?
(Isa 30.3, 5, 7; Ezek 29.6, 7) See, you are relying on Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who rely on him.

(2 Kings 18.4, 5) But if you say to me, ‘We rely on the LORD our God,’ [[is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, ‘You shall worship before this altar’?]] (Gk lacks: Heb adds is it not he…this altar’?)
Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders on them.
(Isa 20.5; 37.29) How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master’s servants, when you rely on Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?
Moreover, is it without the LORD that I have come up against this land to destroy it? The LORD said to me, Go up against this land, and destroy it.”

(v 13|ISA 36:13; Ezra 4.7) Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it; do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”

But the Rabshakeh said, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you and not to the people sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and drink their own urine?”
(2 Chr 32.18) Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah, “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!
(Isa 37.10) Thus says the king: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you.
(v 18) Do not let Hezekiah make you rely on the LORD by saying, ‘The LORD will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’

(Prov 5.15; Zech 3.10) Do not listen to Hezekiah, for thus says the king of Assyria: Make your peace with me and come out to me; then every one of you will eat from your own vine and your own fig tree and drink water from your own cistern,
until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards.
(v 15) Do not let Hezekiah mislead you by saying, ‘The LORD will deliver us.’ Has any of the gods of the nations delivered their land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
(2 Kings 17.6; Isa 37.11-13) Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
(v 15|ISA 36:15; 1 Kings 20.23, 28) Who among all the gods of these countries have delivered their countries out of my hand, that the LORD should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?”
But they were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”

(v 3|ISA 36:3; Isa 22.15, 20) Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.
